title: Visual representations in object substitution masking
abstractText:
If asked to say exactly what they were seeing at any instant, most people would describe an extended three dimensional scene containing objects and animals of various sizes, shapes and colours.  The fact is, however, that at any instant a person sees in detail and in colour only the very small part of the world on which they are fixating - although they may make up to 3 or 4 such fixations each second.  This project is concerned with the sequence of representations that need to be derived from these limited input samples in order that we come to experience the visual world as continuously present to us in detail.


The project will investigate a recently discovered phenomenon known as Object Substitution Masking (OSM).  In OSM a briefly presented target object, such as a face, is difficult to recognize if it is surrounded by four dots that remain present after the face has gone, even though recognition is easy if the dots come on and go off at the same time as the face.  Experiments will test the theory that OSM results from the activity of dynamic feedback loops within the visual system.
